data.title: My New Student Doesn't Speak English
data.meta_description: Welcome to Part 3 in a series, "My New Student Doesn't Speak English."
data.text:
Welcome to Part 3 in a series, ‚ÄúMy New Student Doesn‚Äôt Speak English.‚Äù

In case you missed Part 1 (Environment) and/or Part 2 (Instruction), I‚Äôll put links to both at the bottom of this post.

Today I‚Äôm going to share with you some tips and strategies to help you assess your beginning English Learner student(s).

We can‚Äôt asses our newcomers the same way we would our native English speakers, or even the same way we would with our intermediate or higher level ELs.

Imagine that you are a student who just moved to a foreign country where you do NOT speak the language. I imagine myself being in China, a place where the alphabet system is completely different. I‚Äôd be absolutely lost there, yet I‚Äôd be expected to learn the same content as native Chinese speakers AND I‚Äôd be assessed and graded on my knowledge of that content. Can you imagine?!?! Personally, I‚Äôd be a deer in headlights with an extremely high level of anxiety!

It‚Äôs important for you to know what your new student ‚Äúcan do‚Äù when he/she comes to you. That‚Äôs your starting point‚Ä¶your base-line data. Gotta love data! You will now be measuring (assessing) your new student on the progress he/she makes from this point. ***We are assessing what they can do from this point forward, not what they can‚Äôt do.***

MUST- DOS‚Ä¶modify assessments, provide alternative assessments, allow your students to ‚Äúshow‚Äù what he/she knows in a way that he/she can.

In the beginning, non-English speakers may only be able to point, or gesture, or use limited vocabulary. Soon they can match, identify and label. Is this more than they could do? Yes? Progress!

CAN-DO Descriptors are an excellent resource to help you gauge what your ELs ‚Äúcan do.‚Äù These descriptors are from WIDA. They have the PERFECT name, right?‚Ä¶so glad it‚Äôs not another acronym to remember. üôÇ

(WIDA is a consortium that creates English language proficiency assessments. Many of the states in the U.S. use these assessments annually to measure the progress of ELLs.)

CAN-DO Descriptors show YOU what your ELsHo ‚Äúcan do‚Äù at each level of language proficiency. Visit the website below, and on the right hand side, under ‚ÄúDownloads & Products,‚Äù you‚Äôll see the descriptors organized by grade level. Print out your grade level. I keep a copy in my lesson plan book. This really helps me choose the best ways to differentiate instruction and assessments according to my students‚Äô proficiency levels.

https://www.wida.us/standards/CAN_DOs/

CAN-DO Descriptors for Grades 3-5: Reading & Writing

CAN-DO Descriptors for Grades 3-5: Listening & Speaking

Below are the descriptors taken from the above charts to show what a Level 1 student CAN-DO. Notice the verbs. When thinking about how you will assess your newcomer, think about how they are able to ‚Äúshow‚Äù you what they know.

CAN-DO Descriptions for Level 1 (beginning) ELLs

In order to set students up for success, we need to provide tasks that our English language learners ‚Äúcan do.‚Äù Giving them the same assessment as their native English speaking peers will not give valid results if the students can‚Äôt understand what is being asked of them.

Here are some tips for creating modified assessments:

1. Simplify and reduce the language.

2. Use meaningful visuals.

3. Provide scaffolds, like word banks or sentence stems.

4. Use the CAN-DO descriptors to help create a modified assessment.

5. Test key concepts/essential knowledge.

6. Allow students to show their understanding in multiple ways (illustrate, act out, label, answer

orally, match, etc.)

7. Provide a bilingual dictionary in your students home language if they are literate in their home

language (L1).

At times, if my newcomer does not perform well on an assessment, I will take a close look at the type of assessment I gave and think about 2 things in particular‚Ä¶First, did I teach it in a way that they understood, or do I need to reteach? Second, did I provide them with an appropriate assessment? Perhaps I‚Äôll give them an opportunity to show what they know using a different format.

With a welcoming and safe environment, instruction that is carefully planned with appropriate scaffolds, and assessments that are differentiated and modified, your newcomers will grow, learn, and be successful in their new educational setting.

I hope you have found this information helpful. I‚Äôd highly recommend printing out a copy of the Can-Do Descriptors and keeping it in your plan book. Along with the descriptors, there is a chart called ‚ÄúCan-Do Name Charts.‚Äù These are fill-able charts so that you can add your students‚Äô names under their level of proficiency. What a great tool in helping to differentiate for our students. This resource is new, as far as I know, and I definitely plan on using it this year.
